content.statement: trauma-018-fasciotomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Trauma Principles Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding trauma-018-fasciotomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of trauma-018-fasciotomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of trauma-018-fasciotomy.

therapeutic: Clinical signs of compartment syndrome (6 Ps)
Pain out of proportion to injury with passive stretch

early: Pain out of proportion to visible injury
Pain with passive stretch of compartment muscles
clinical_signs_compartment_syndrome.important_note: Pulses may be present even with compartment syndrome - do not rely on pulses alone

anterior.contents: Tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, deep peroneal nerve

lateral.contents: Peroneus longus and brevis, superficial peroneal nerve

deep_posterior.contents: Tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, posterior tibial artery/nerve
deep_posterior.access: Medial incision, release soleus off tibia

lateral_incision.location: Midway between tibial crest and fibula
lateral_incision.length: Full length of leg (knee to ankle)

medial_incision.key_step: Must detach soleus from tibia to access deep posterior

key_principles: Incisions must be full length of compartment
All four compartments must be released
Fascia must be incised, not just skin
Apply negative pressure wound therapy or wet-to-dry dressings

wound_management.initial: Leave fasciotomy wounds open, wet dressings or NPWT
wound_management.debridement: Return to OR at 24-48 hours for second look if concern

closure.skin_grafting: If delayed primary closure not possible

timely_fasciotomy.complications: Wound healing, infection, need for skin grafting

definition.@value: Surgical release of fascial compartments to prevent or treat compartment syndrome, indicated prophylactically after prolonged ischemia or therapeutically with elevated compartment pressures

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Identify indications for prophylactic vs therapeutic fasciotomy
Recognize clinical signs of compartment syndrome
Describe the four compartments of the lower leg and their contents
Perform a two-incision four-compartment fasciotomy technique
Manage fasciotomy wounds and plan for closure
clinical_pearls: Ischemia >4-6 hours = prophylactic fasciotomy at time of revascularization
Pain with passive stretch is the earliest and most reliable sign of compartment syndrome
Pulses may be present with compartment syndrome - do not rely on pulses
'When in doubt, cut it out' - err on side of fasciotomy
All FOUR compartments must be released in the lower leg
Must release soleus off tibia to access deep posterior compartment

medicalCode.description: Division of right lower leg subcutaneous tissue and fascia, open approach
Decompression fasciotomy, leg; anterior and/or lateral compartments only
